Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 11:41PM trailertrash wrote: My doc prescribed lorazepam (Ativan), which I realize now is too sedating. I'm embarrassed to ask her for xanax, which worked during a terrible crisis several years ago...I worry that she'll think of me as a drug-seeker. And yes, I have a hard time not blurting it out to total strangers, since it's almost all I can think about.
Posts.Title: To tranquilise or not to tranquilise jebdra Momine

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 07:05AM trailertrash wrote: As I work in the cancer field, I have some "insider knowledge" about some of the processes. A very large # of women JUST DIAGNOSED get offered antidepressants (AD's), but 5 years out? I don't get it either. Xanax & narcotic pain meds, I personally think ought to be available in small amounts, to keep for an "as needed" basis. One time I bought a small bottle of OTC codeine in Canada, and I never even used half of it before it expired. Sometimes, some people need something a little stronger than aspirin.
Posts.Title: To tranquilise or not to tranquilise jebdra Momine

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 07:06AM - edited Dec 26, 2012 07:07AM by trailertrash cookiegal: My thoughts exactly. BETTER LIVING THROUGH CHEMISTRY.
Posts.Title: To tranquilise or not to tranquilise jebdra Momine

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 10:39AM trailertrash wrote: It's only natural to think about death! I went between minimizing and catastrophizing. Sometimes within the same sentence! You go ahead and let every roller-coaster emotion take over, in its own good time. You'll reach a state of equilibrium pretty fast. You did nothing wrong, to "cause" cancer; it is just that our cells go awry sometimes. Some researchers theorize that we all have immune systems that are fighting off little developing cancers often...and sometimes, for unknown reasons, some of those errant cells make it it past the body's natural defenses, and develop into a full-blown cancer. Please keep us posted. We really, really understand the tears, fear, dread.
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2012 08:07PM trailertrash wrote: Hello Iles, I'm in about the same time-frame as you are. Mine is tubular, or with tubular components. Consultation with the breast surgeon is this coming Fri the 14th. MRI the day b4. You are perfectly normal, with all the panic, fear, focusing on cancer. I feel the same way sometimes. It's so hard to ALSO work, take care of my son, take care of my pets & house. I called my PCP & upped my usual anti-depressant dose, to help me cope with all this. Amazingly, I work in cancer care and have taken care of literally thousands of people with cancer. I am more blase' about cancer than most people--and yet, when it happened to me, I fell apart just like anybody else would. Big hugs to you.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week,surgery tomorrow -- I'm so frightened. lles Dejaboo

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2012 10:13AM trailertrash wrote: I'm new here, but that list made me well up with tears. My BMX w/o RC is January 10th. May I be added to the list? I'm having an emotional day. I work full-time & have a high-maintenance son, so I "keep it together" much of the time, but if I find myself awake& he's asleep, the fears & grief start sweeping over me.

And with the other setbacks. Crap. I think having the drains out was a really happy time.Â  I'm so sorry you've grown an extra breast on the side, that would be a huge pain! I'm sure LE therapy will make it go away, but I don't think it is quite that fast. Can you have a little more time off from work?

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 09:12PM trailertrash wrote: I'm seeing my name in print, for reasons none of us want...and I see it says I'm having recon. But I'm not. I don't have any idea how to fix this! I'll start with my own profile, to make sure that matches.
Posts.Title: January 2013 surgery JRMH Lbwagner69

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 09:55PM trailertrash wrote: To Di2012, Amazing to me, that you could do pushups--I'm 5 weeks out, and it'll be a few more days at least before I could do that. The burning pain under the whole chest skin makes me hold off on chest exercise. I do take long walks with a strong dog, with the leash tied around my waist. but chest exercises? No flippin' WAY. Neurontin is helping the burning a lot, no side effects to speak of. Doing the long walks, bicep, tricep & back exercises. But even slight pushing/pulling makes the burning come back. I respect pain as a signal to back off, so none of that for me. Yet :-)
Posts.Title: January 2013 surgery JRMH Lbwagner69
